posts.text:
I try to be more conscious now of this sort of thing in my work now, but I'm confident it's pervasive across the industry anywhere people have access to dedicated compute.

Below some threshold time cost, the urge to avoid expending cognitive energy has the potential to drive tremendous waste.

reply_context.text: ... Eventually it occurred to me that I was effectively engaging in the energy consumption equivalent of turning on a cement factory for several minutes to do simple math like "8/6=?" which I could just as easily do in my browser, terminal, on paper, in my head, etc. ...

posts.text: so prob not a "lottery ticket" situation since the lower rank information is probably "smeared" across multiple hidden dimensions. we cant just drop hidden dims en toto because the information we need is in superposition.

reply_context.text: what I was suggesting was that instead of leaning on high D representations to shortcut us into shared even higher D kernels, theres prob more "native" operators we can find/learn that are happy to work with those lower D representations.

posts.text: what I was suggesting was that instead of leaning on high D representations to shortcut us into shared even higher D kernels, theres prob more "native" operators we can find/learn that are happy to work with those lower D representations.

reply_context.text: my interpretation of the current state of affairs is that it's like applying the kernel trick to those 42 dimensions. the fundamental latent might be expressible in some small space, but not linearly workable in that space.

posts.text:
Waymo should be held liable for failing to automate a minimal "don't make the problem worse" (e.g. pulling over) response to a citywide crisis.

Imagine if this were an emergency necessitating large scale evacuations. San Francisco is due for a 100-year earthquake, and CA spent last summer on fire.

Something I think is particularly interesting about this is that even though it's probably right: the notion of a modern LM with a hidden dim of 42 is ridiculous. Given that we need orders of magnitude more representational dimensions to do useful things rn, that suggests an inefficiency somewhere.
